bibl.title: Letter from J. F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 6, 1928

div1.p: Siler asks Kean for information about Hildebrand and his participation in the yellow fever experiments. A handwritten note explains that Reed did not allow Hildebrand to be bitten by a mosquito because of his age. They did allow him to be a part of the fomite experiments. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from J. F. Siler to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 6, 1928
div1.opener:
S.G.O. 032.1-2
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
jfs-svl
April 6, 1928
Memorandum for:
General J. R. Kean, U.S. Army, Retired,
Army Medical Museum and Library,
7th and B Streets, S.W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am inclosing herewith a letter from Mr. Gruenberg which is
self-explanatory. There is also attached hereto a copy of my reply
to him.

Knowing that you have complete knowledge of the part
Hildebrand played in this work and that you can give Mr. Gruenberg
complete information, I have taken the liberty of writing him that
we have referred this letter to you for reply.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler J. F. Siler,
Lt. Colonel, Medical Corps.
2 incls.
Major Reed refused to let Pvt. Hildebrand be bitten
by infected mosquitos in spite of his offer to submit
to such experiments because of his being over 40 years
of age as the mortality rate is much higher in advanced
age. He underwent the fomites experiment & for this was placed on
the Y. F. Roll of Honor Feb. 28, 1929, with pension $100 a month
